segments.text: I'd be crazy not to ask this question. So recently you were on 60 Minutes and you talked about AI
potentially curing all diseases within the next decade. How would that exactly work? Would
regulation slow things down? Yeah. So let me just clarify what I meant by there. And you can have
the scoop on this is like, well, look, what I was meaning was a platform that could come up with
many hundreds of drugs, right? Now, whether or not, of course, there's all the FDA and all the
other regulatory approvals and things like that, that might change over time to probably slower
than a decade. So but that doesn't mean those potential cures wouldn't exist in the world.
Maybe it'll take another decade to get it through all the processes and regulation. But
on the other hand, I could imagine once those types of drugs are proven out, maybe the first
five or six AI design drugs, we can backtest whether the predictions were right on them in
terms of, you know, side effects and that kind of thing. And then you might update the regulatory
to sort of be, you know, they accept the predictions a little bit more that they're
reliable or statistically know how much reliability there is in that. So I can imagine that changing
over time too. But first things first, we got to build out our biochemistry and build on top of
alpha fold and build all of our new, you know, small molecule design systems and so on, which
is going very well at isomorphic. But we've got a good few years of that to do first. And then,
and then we'll see about the next steps. So accelerating personalized treatment is really
what AI will help with. I think so. And look, you know, the thing I point back to is a lot of people
are skeptical about that timeline and they're probably, you know, it's very reasonable to be
skeptical of that because usually it takes a decade to do one drug, right? And you're doing
well with if that's the case, but it's the same thing that we were told when we started AlphaFold,
you know, it takes a PhD student, rule of thumb, you know, most basically their whole PhD to
crystallize and find the find the structure one protein, right, five years on average,
one protein. And now with AlphaFold, we've done all 200 million proteins known to science
in in one year, which is, you know, a billion years of PhD time. So we've done it once,
you know, in what was thought to be a kind of uncrackable problem. And, you know, grand
challenge of biology. This is harder, of course, because human body, but I'm optimistic it's
possible. And we're going to try really, really hard to do it.

paragraphs.text: I'd be crazy not to ask this question. Recently, you were on 60 Minutes, and you talked about AI potentially curing all diseases within the next decade. How would that exactly work?

Regulation slow things down? Let me clarify what I meant there. And you can have the scoop on this: what I meant was a platform that could come up with many hundreds of drugs. Of course, there are all the FDA and other regulatory approvals and things like that, which might change over time, probably slower than a decade. But that doesn't mean those potential cures wouldn't exist in the world. Maybe it'll take another decade to get them through all the processes and regulation.

pBut on the other hand, I could imagine once those types of drugs are proven outmaybe the first five or six AI-designed drugswe can backtest whether the predictions were right on them in terms of side effects and that kind of thing. Then you might update the regulatory framework to be that they accept the predictions a little bit more, that they're reliable, or statistically know how much reliability there is in that. I can imagine that changing over time too.

pBut first things first, we have to build out our biochemistry, build on top of AlphaFold, and build all of our new small molecule design systems and so on, which is going very well at Isomorphic. But we have a good few years of that to do first. Then we'll see about the next steps.

pAccelerating personalized treatment is really what AI will help with, I think so. The thing I point back to is that a lot of people are skeptical about that timeline, and it's very reasonable to be skeptical of that because usually it takes a decade to do one drug. And you're doing well if that's the case. But it's the same thing that we were told when we started AlphaFold: a PhD student, as a rule of thumb, essentially dedicates their whole PhD to crystallizing and finding the structure of one proteinfive years on average, one protein. Now with AlphaFold, we've done all 200 million proteins known to science in one year, which is a billion years of PhD time. We've done it once in what was thought to be an uncrackable problem. A grand challenge of biology. This is harder, of course, because it involves the human body, but I'm optimistic it's possible. And we're going to try really, really hard to do it.
